sp.p: I wish hee were hang'd, he makes me tell a hundred lies in a weeke in telling him ye are not within, of purpose to be rid of him.

sp.speaker: Sir. T.
sp.p: Here's a rogue.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Alasse for's businesse, were my case, if any body wud but give me a sawcer of Mustard for't, he shud have it.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Sawcy rascall.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Suppose he brings his action, what can he doe in 't?— not this, tis true, he wud have retain'd me to have taken out a Writ against ye, but when I perceived that it was nothing but a malicious humor, I bid him goe and be hang'd with this brabbles, I wud not be troubled with 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir▪ T.
sp.p: Very good, but you were willing enough to be troubled with my money, I have heard you all this while, and this your sucking knave too.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Sir Timothy, come, come, Ime glad you are come, Ime glad you are here with all my heart, come, I must have you made friends by all meanes.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Friends? Ile see him stand bare to the taile of a Cart first, I friends with him?— hang him rascall.

sp.speaker: Sir. P,
sp.p:
Sir, I make no doubt but I shall make you know, and your daughter too before I have done with her, that shee has abus'd my sonne, I cannot tell, I will not say she has bewitch'd him, but if I prove it, Ile make ye all stinke with a
vengeance.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Why, ye worme-eaten slave, does my daughter looke like a Witch?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Budget, pray ye put downe worme-eaten slave, and the day of the moneth too, bee heare?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Didst not come thy selfe (you whorson gull?)

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Write ye whoreson gull.

sp.speaker: Budg.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Didst not come, thy selfe, I say to know what portion I wud give her? Now I find it was but a meere pretence, ye cheating rogue you.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Write ye cheating rogue you.

sp.speaker: Budg.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: If my man Hilts were here I wud beate thy very nose into thy face, and afterwards beat it out agen.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: What wud ye doe sir?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Nay pray gentlemen forbeare while ye are in my house.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: I can forbeare him no longer.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Come sit Timothy, pray goe along with me.

sp.speaker: Budg.
sp.p: Sir Plenteous, pray ye goe along with me sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Prethee let me beate the rogue first.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Nay come sir, come, come.

div.stage: Exit Muchcraft with Sir Thomas, Budget with sir Plen.
Enter Sabina, Valentine, Fairefaith, Sportlove, Trash, Rowland.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Why so?
This is the crowne of all our joyes on earth,
When love and marriage trippe it hand in hand,
Jt makes the minde to vault
And caper o're the clouds of discontent;
Me thinkes my soule has wings and I cud fly,
From hence t' Elizium, come cheere up my sweete,
What art thou sad, and see thy husband laugh?
Come now we are married, we must have but one
Passion betwixt us— Gentlemen what?
Frownes at a Wedding?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: How? frownes?
Shud a man seeme to droope or hang the wings
At such a time, he were farre fitter for
T'accompany wild Tygers in a wood,
Then to converse with men, the gods themselves
Sing Epithalamies, when mortals wed,
If Gods are subject to these passions, then
They needes must over-sway the hearts of men;
Sir, joyes attend ye, may you ever be
As full of joyes, as we are now to see
Your happy Nuptialls:
Pish, be not so sad cosin.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.l: Come leave this dull discourse, and let us fill,
Our active soules up to the brimme with joy;

Come,
Sings.
FArewell this company,
If you love sadnesse,
For melancholy is,
Nothing but madnesse;
Hang up proud costly cloathes,
Pedlers and pack toyes;
Let us make the hogs-heads weepe,
Claret and sacke boyes.
Are there no Fidlers in this world?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Sir, I wud they wud come once, my very heeles are up ith' aire already me thinkes in this humour, I cud wish the whole world were a Morrice dance for foure & forty houres outright.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: O thou egregious puppy, if the whole world were a Morris dance for foure and fortie houres outright, what shud, nay, what does thou thinke wud the good people of New England doe all that while.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: I doe thinke they wud pray for a timely cessation of the noise of the superstitious bells hanging about their knees.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: A most damnable witch in my conscience.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Come sweet-heart, rush up your spirits, put on a resolution to be jocund; thinke but on what must passe betwixt us two this very night;
sp.l: How I must revill in thy armes, and then
How thou must tumble in my bosome;
And that I know will be enough to purge
Sad contemplations.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, pray you excuse me;
Troublesome thinges doe whisper in my eare,
Which for the present J cannot expell.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Pish.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Doe not heede or nusle the least sad thought
At such a time, tell 'em some other time
You'le sit and heare their grievances.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: Ay, ay, doe so, what? upon your joviall day be sad? but where be these Fidlers?

sp.speaker: Musi.
sp.p: We are come sir.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.l: Pray ye play then.
Come, a song, a song.

div.head: A Song.
div.l: IOy, health, and pleasure, waite upon
This louely paire,
May all your dayes like to this one
Be void of care,
And may those twinkling starres of night
Attend your bed,
That so the bridegroome may get right
Your maydenhead.
And let Arabian odours then
Perfume thy sheets;
Strewing thy chamber once agen
With daintie sweets,
Then let these pretty thoughts that move
A flame in Cupids fires,
Bring ye to bed where you may prove
The things that love desires.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Come, these Nuptiall rites being done,
It now remaines we speed it to the bed,
Where we will arme in arme discourse and act
Loves pretty handy dandyes— Gentlemen
— speake—
Has not my starres beene kinde,
To grace my Fortunes with so faire a blisse.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Sir, ye enjoy a happinesse beyond
Expression or compare.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p:
Nay sir, Ile promise ye this, that as long as she is your wife, no man breathing shall ere bring Acteons punishment
upon your head— I will not say what the woman may doe, and that's a rare blessing Rowland betwixt you and me, I can tell yee.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Me thinkes I see
My selfe now dandl'd on the knee of Fate.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.l: Sir, you doe now embrace
A richer veine than ere the Sunne beheld,
And I presume none save your onely selfe,
Whose presence is a treasure of enchantments,
Could have prevail'd so farre with her, whose eye
Ne're yet cast glance of love upon a man,
Therefore doe I pronounce
You th' onely minion both of Fame and Fate.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Nay, you are a happy man, that's certaine sir, if all men had such wives, we shud have a strange world, for then we shud be troubled neither with children nor cuckholds.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Well gentlemen golden slumbers attend ye,
Come faire one, come, we have too long defer'd
The love embraces of the marriage bed,
O how it rapps my soule to thinke that I
This very houre with my faire love must lie,
Rak't up in cinders, love may burne, but when
It 'gin's to flame, it fires both gods and men;
Come.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pray ye sir forbeare a little.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I will sweet-heart.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Cosin Fairefaith, a word, you have brought me here upon a businesse will utterly disgrace me; what will this gentleman thinke of me dee thinke, when he findes that I have gull'd him thus.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Come, come, put your feates to sleepe,

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Nay, come sweete-heart, why these delayes?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Pray yee sir deale gently with her, she's yong and fearefull to lie with a man, and that's the businesse sir, that makes her so loth t'unpin.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Alas poore soule, in my conscience you had rather lie with a woman, than with these rude men behalfe, wud not ye forsooth?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Come, give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Why? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nothing sir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Nothing? I know tis something; are not you well?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: What's the reason yee will not goe to bed then? pray ye come without more adoe.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Fie upon't cosin, a woman wud scorne these things.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Nay, yee are ith' right sir, I doe beleeve she wud defie it.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Come, what's the businesse with ye? will ye not goe to bed— ha?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, Ile consider of it presently.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: How, consider of it?
Am I a man? a married man? or what?
Am I a husband? must a husband then
Entreate his wife?
Is Nature growne so old she has forgot
To teach her children what belongs unto
Their different places?
Although before I was content to bend
My spirits to your foote, yet know, that now
The will of Fate has destin'd me to be
Next under it the sole, commander of
Your minde and person, therefore now I must,
Nay, I will be obey'd.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Pray ye doe not fright her too much, she's a very tender hearted thing forsooth— pray ye speake her faire.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Hold you your prating sirra, she shall observe my will now.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: You'le never doe good sir with foule meanes.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: By your favour my friend, I know this out of my owne knowledge, that a froward sharpe husband will presently make a woman doe what she list.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Stoppe your mouthes.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p:
Sir, for my part I will not stop my mouth, I understand
what I say sir, I'me a married man my selfe sir, and 'tis well knowne to be true, that I cud never yet get any thing of my wife by harsh words.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Once more I bid you hold your babling.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, she shall not goe to bed till shee has a minde to goe to bed, nor I will not hold my babling neither sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Hold your peace Trash.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: You'le close your mouth by and by I hope.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes marry will J sir, but not at your bidding sir: what now— what dee thinke I'me a foole in a Play?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Will you hold your tongue or no?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes forsooth and please your worship.

div.stage: Sabina takes hold of him, and offers to strike him.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: This insolence I cannot beare,
And for your part you are my wife, and one
In whom obedience ought to be exprest,
And I your top.

sp.speaker: Trash.
sp.p: Ay, you want but a little whipping.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: What say you sirra?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I say, a woman that has a good husband, and all things else, and will not goe to bed, wants nothing but whipping.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Well, 'tis thus,
If milde intreaties, nor a gentle fawne;
Nor protestations, nor a husbands love
Can mollifie thy Stubbornesse, nor bring
Thy sturdy disposition to my hand;
Ile for a time quite turne out of my thoughts
A husbands pitties, and where smiles did faile,
A lustie bastinado shall perswade
— What shall I be bafled thus
Out of my pleasures with a womans blush;
Ist fit that I stand pleading where my starres
Bid me command? I scorne it, therefore speake
This very present minute, nay before
You fetch more breath, speake either ay, or no,
Or I must strike, there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: We shall have the Peace broken, here presently, I see that.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Peace, quoth a? nay and my head be not broken I care not.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: Come, she is content to goe sir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Give the word.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, I will goe to bed.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Come your wayes then.

div.stage: Exit Sabina leading Valentine; Trash falls into a laughter.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: dee heare gentlemen, dee heare?
What if this gentleman shud get my Master with childe now?

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: Nay, what if your Master shud get that gentleman with childe.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I cannot tell what hee may doe for men, but I ne're knew him doe such a courtesie for a woman yet.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Mr. Fairefaith, pray tell me one thing, why did you being my Masters kinsman, and an old souldier stand so patiently, and see him so affronted.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: J that's true indeede Rowland, he being an old beaten souldier too.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: A beaten souldier?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: An old souldier I meane sir.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I confesse I had no disposition to medle in't, because J know they'le agree themselves, I know the bowels of the businesse, which you doe not, come, goe along, and by the way Ile tell ye the plot.

lg.l: And then wee'le bring this newes
To blesse the eares of old sir Timothy,
Strength I confesse may make a Gyant yeeld,
But give me policie to winne the field. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: Actus Quintus.
div.stage: Enter Mirabell, Hilts before, and Kate behinde.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O My poore sister!

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: There's no question but we shall finde her, how long has she beene wanting forsooth?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: A great while Kate, a little faster, what shall I tread upon your heeles?— not so fast neither.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p:
What the devill ayles ye? too soft, and then too fast, here's more adoe with you, than with all the Pageants in
my Lord Majors show; he that waites on you, had neede to have his steppes prick'd out with a paire of Compasses, for ought I see.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What a surly groome are you, may not one speake to you?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Speake? yes forsooth you may speake, but I doe not love to walke before a Gentlewoman like one of these gingerly youthes that goe before their Mistresses, as if the streets were pav'd with egges, not I.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Why, how now sir sawce boxe, what is't all fellowes with ye, ye filthy, stinking, sawcy, dirty, scabbed, paltry, lousie, mangie rogue ye.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Heyda, Mistresse Iuniper, what's the matter with you tro? you were not us'd to be so snappish, I'me sure on't, I have both gone and rid before you, and you ne're found fault with it.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: O ye lying rascall, did ye ever ride before me in your life?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Yes marry have I forsooth.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: 'Tis as false a tale Mistresse as ever was told; 'tis true, he rid before me one night a little short journey; 'twas nothing, I cud even a gone as farre a soote upon the matter.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Who doubts that forsooth?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Why will you lie then ye rascall?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Why, whats the businesse? what the mischiefe ayles ye? sure ye have not made water today I thinke.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Come Hilts come, you shud beare with her.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Beare forsooth, shee shud beare, shee's us'd too 'it, more than I am forsooth.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: What shud I beare pray? suffer such an Asse as you to ride upon my backe, shud I not?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Why not? aswell as alwayes upon your belly forsooth?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Come, come, pray ye goe along, we have something else to thinke on than stand here.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Very well sir, I shall thinke upon your words.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: This way forsooth?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Yes, yes, goe on.

div.stage: Enter Sir Timothy with officers meeting them.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: How now daughter, whether are you going?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: To see if I can finde my sister sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Come, come, doe not trouble your selfe to no purpose, I have order'd it already, Ile have these men goe that have authority to make the doores and gates flie open where they come and goe, and dee heare Officers, looke too 'it, and be sure to search very narrowly the places that I told ye of, and especially the house where young Crambagge is suspected to lie, and if yee finde either one or both of 'em, bring 'em away, dee heare?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: We shall sir. Exeunt Officer.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Daughter, I rather thinke (to put her selfe out of th-way of this approaching disparagement) shee has runne her selfe upon some desperate course.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: But dee thinke these men will finde her sir?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: I cannot tell, wee shall know presently.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Doe not weepe Mistresse, I hope shee's well, and will be here agen shortly.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Come, come, lets have no weeping.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Doe not you greeve, and for them 'tis not a pinne matter, let them alone, weeping is as wholesome for a woman sir as making of water.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Had she but bid farewell
'Twud not have troubled me so much;
But thus to goe away—

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Ne're feare, shee's well enough Ile warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Oh Hilts,
Her high borne spirit cannot brooke disgrace,
And I doe feare these mischiefes will provoke
Some violent hand upon her selfe;
yet me thinks one thing
Whispers my understanding in the eare,
And tells me she is safe;
There's not a jewell, ring, or bracelet left
That ere she wore, but is convey'd away.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Nay then sir feare nothing, for if shee had so much wit to carry away her rings and jewells, she has wit enough to keepe her selfe from killing or drowning, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: O heavens!
With what a swinge is youth,
Hurri'd along the world and subject still,
Vnto the rule of an unbridl'd will:
Oh!
Pitty those Parents then, who oftentimes
Are brought unto their graves by children crimes;
In, in, and comfort your selfe;
Ile see these Officers dispatcht away,

div.stage: Exeunt Hilts, Mirabell, Kate at one doore, Sir Timothy at the other.
Enter Valentine unbutton'd as out of bed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Rowland, Rowland, Rowland; I say.

div.stage: Enter Rowland as newly awaked.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What's the matter here?
Wast you that call'd sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It was I.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: What wud ye have sir, are not ye well?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I wud I were.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I'me sorry you are not well sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Call Trash, call Trash.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Trash, Trash.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: What's the matter? Within.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Come presently, you master's not well;
Hes comming sir, what wud ye please to have sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing at all.

div.stage: Enter trash yawning and rubbing his eyes.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Rowland, where art foole?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Here, here man, whether dost goe?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: What's the matter Rowland— ha?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Your Master's not well here.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Not well? O alas! Ile runne and fetch some hot water presently.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Stay, whether dee goe? come your wayes hither, what will you fetch man, I'me not sicke.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Not? you're but a yawling rascall Rowland for waking of me, I was in the daintiest sleepe, and the sweetest dreame; me thought my Master was in bed with the bravest wench—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Twas too true.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: How? was it too true? introth, I thanke yee for nothing, you ne're dream'd so for me I'me sure on't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O Rowland, I'me undone, I'me undone.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: What's the matter sir?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Ile warrant yee the gentleman that went to bed with him, finding himselfe cosen'd has kill'd himselfe, or one mischiefe or other, I thought no good wud come on't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, no, 'twas a woman all the while, 'twas a woman.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: 'Twas a woman good man simple, what? dost thou thinke that I dreame out of Aesops Fables?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: 'Twud vexe a man to marry in jest, and then to have it prove plaine earnest, Ile assure yee that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O Trash, I'me undone.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Why undone sir, why dee say so, and please your worship.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ime married man, I'me married with a vengeance,

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Why so am I too sir; but how shud we helpe it, can ye tell that sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O Rowland, what shall I doe? where shall I goe? where shall I runne?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Run quoth a? nay, if you'r married once, Ile trust ye for running.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am married, and I know not to whom, did I but know that.

sp.speaker: Trash.
sp.p: That's no great matter, 'tis but going to the Church Booke, and you may know that presently.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Accursed Fate, what marriages might I have had? to what a pitch might I have mounted up my fortunes? which now I see are nothing but confusion:
sp.l: Who knowes what strumpet this may be,
Some queane for ought I know, that thinkes to raise
Her selfe out of my ruines:
Now my perplexed thought begin to burne
With flames of guilt:
Now comes my trembling soule unto the barre
Of my owne knowledge:
O Sabina, Sabina!
The gods now tumble vengeance on my head
For wrongs to thee;
Had I beene well advis'd, O then I might
Have layne by thy faire side, where every touch:
Had beene as tender as a bed of downe.
And every smile a heaven;
But 'tis too late,
To call backe what is past, it was my fate,
And there's an end;
Now am I round entrench'd with miseries;
One side a marriage nips me in the bud;
On th'other side, a rankrous enemie,
Old Testy, who still gazes on the print
Of our mistaken step, therefore 'tis now
No time to pause, packe up my cloathes this night,
I doe intend to save my selfe by flight:
Trash, about it presently.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Yes and please your worship.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But dee heare, let not my Landlady, nor her husband have so much as a glimpse of it, for I have no money for 'em.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Nay sir, if you intend to travell, be sure ye take all your money along with ye, especially if you meane to be merry, for you shall finde that money is the most daintie companion sir; but Rowland, dee heare? scatter no words.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By no meanes.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Not a word sir;
sp.stage: Exeunt Valentine and Trash, manet Rowland.
sp.l: Travell quoth a? here's a peece of worke indeede:
O Mr. Welt, how dee sir, how does my Landlady— ha?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Very well, how dee you Rowland?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Troth, pretty well, Servingman like, carelesse of much, proud of a little, drunke for want of wit, and sometimes sober for want of money.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: I thought ye had beene sicke, because I have not seene yee this long time.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Sicke quoth a? my pockets are a little cowardly now and then indeede, that's all my sicknesse.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: What? wud ye have 'em quarrelsome?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Quarrelsome? no, but I wud have 'em to have a little more mettall in 'em for all that.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Wher's your Master pray?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Nay I know not, I have not seene him this sixe houres.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: There is a little money due to me from him, I wish he wud take the payment of it into consideration, I have extraordinary occasion to use the money, if he please to let me have but some of it, it will doe mee a courtesie, he shall finde me reasonable.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: How idlely you talke husband? Is that a way to live in the world, doe you thinke it is for my ease to have gentlemen come, and lie in my house, and goe away and pay nothing— ha?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Pay? yes good sweetheart, why shud he not pay; there's no body speakes against that, sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why doe you talke so foolishly then of being reasonable, and I cannot tell what, I doe not like such words I tell ye truely;— reasonable quoth a? Eate my meate, drinke my drinke, burne my wood, foule my roomes, weare my sheets, make use of my servants, and yet I must be reasonable; if ye can talke no wiselier before folkes, pray ye hold your peace and let your wife speake— besides, yee know he owes me both for bootes, shooes, and pantables, and I shall give him that too shall not I? no indeede forsooth, I wud have your Master to know that I do not buy my lether so cheape, Ile assure ye— be reasonable quoth a? besides, I have promis'd to pay Mr. Sugerbox the Chandler, nutmegges and sugar for his mornings draughts, and Mr. Dash the Vintener for wine in's chamber, and shall I pay them before your Master has paid me— introth I doe not meane it.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: 'Tis fit a gentleman shud pay you before, that's the truth of it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ye say right Rowland, I see you have more consideration with yee than my husband has— be reasonable quoth a?— marry whoope.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Why dee keepe all this stirre, my Master's not running away woman— here's a quarter indeede, if hee will be ruled by me, he shall not give you one farthing, because you keepe such a coile.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
How keepe such a coile ye jacke sawee? how now? such a coile? dee thinke ye are talking to your companions sirra? such a coile? and in my owne house too sirra? and you
must stand by forsooth like Iohn a Noakes, and see every Servingman runne upon me in this manner; remember this when ye come to bed; and for your Masters not paying of me, ye Sawcebox, I'me at the better end of the staffe with him, for I have lockt up all his clothes; nay if you'r so Sawcy, Ile fit him, Ile warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Ye will?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes indeede will I?

div.stage: Enter Trash.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Rowland, Rowland, Rowland, theeves, theeves, theeves, theeves, Rowland, theeves.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: How now? how now?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: All my Masters clothes are stolne quite a way Rowland, all stolne every jot, breeches, doublet, boots, spurres, cloaks, gownes, hats, bands, cuffes, ruffes, caps, shooes, shirts, all gone, all stolne, every jot.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Here's the theefe.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Where? where?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Here I say.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Who, my Landlady, did you steale my Masters clothes— ha? wherefore pray ye?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Steale 'em? no sir J scorne it; I tooke 'em indeede, and Ile justifie it; and more than so sir, I have lockt 'em up, and Ile justifie that too.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: How? lockt up my Masters clothes, wherefore I pray ye?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Wherefore? doe not yee know your Master owes me money? doe not you know I have often askt it, and cannot get it? doe not ye know that it is a pretty summe? doe not you know that it is for meate, drinke, lodging, fire, and candle-light, washing, wringing, and starching; besides, boots, shooes, pantables, and galosheas: if, I had the Booke I cud shew ye.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Nay, you're perfect enough without booke for ought I see. Enter Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Trash, Your Master's come home, and you must come to him presently. Exit Boy.

div.stage: Exeunt Trash, Welt and his wife.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Here's a creature Ile sweare upon a booke, this woman has no bones in her tongue, if any man love trumpets, there's a noise for him, sure I doe not thinke but this Shoomaker's a witch, he wud never a contracted himselfe to the devill else.

div.stage: Enter Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What, are ye here? and I have nothing put up yet?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Sir, your clothes are all put up, and safe under locke and key.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay then 'tis no matter; who put 'em up?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: That did my Landlady sir, shee has lockt 'em up, and sweares she'le keepe 'em safe till she can perswade ye to part with some pocket mettle sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Enough, enough, I will not be beholden to her, Ile satisfie her.

div.stage: Enter sir Timothy with Officers.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: O sir, have I found ye out in the end, Come Officers lay hold on him— but stay lets talke with ye a little first.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Sure my master was borne when the signe was in Cancer, for whatsoever he does intend, goes alwayes quite backwards, well some body shall know on't presently, that shall fetch him off againe for all this sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Sirra, hold your peace, and
Be gone about your businesse fellow, Exit Rowland.
Dost know what thou hast done? or have my wrongs
Arriv'd at thy understanding yet?— ha?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir I am conscious to my selfe of all
The wrongs and injuries that I have done ye.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Why hast thou put this blemish on my child,
Which like a Canker threatens to deface
My Story, and for ever raze my name
Out of the booke of honour, nay, a spot,
Which time nor date, nor all the brinish waves
Can e're wash out— speake thou detested wretch;
Hadst not a sparke of vertue left within
Thy bosome to preserve thy honour— speake, I say.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: In trembling reverence to your precepts here,
I creepe upon my knees before the barre
Of Your just frownes, I dare not pleade excuse,
No, no, my crimes are writ upon my front
In die of blushing guilt, which nothing but
Your reconciling smiles can ere wash out,
— They, I say, they must be
That expiating sacrifice for me.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Smiles on thee?
Hast thou the face to say thy faults can be
Capable of mercy? go to, marke what I say,
Vnlesse thou canst contrive a way to cure
The wounded reputation of my Girle,
Expect not one commiserating thought,
But all the tortours of severitie
That e're can be inflicted—
Come, come, rise up, it is in vaine to kneele,
My eares are stopt to mercy, nothing now
But onely that can ope them.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, I am content to engage all my possibilities to accomplish your desires.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: There may be some hope in this.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, Devise how I may
But give this satisfaction you require,
And my soule shall study its performance.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: I cannot tell,
Thou hast so plung'd her in a sincke of shame,
— That't will, for ought I know,
Nonplus the world to finde a remedie.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Her case is not so desperate, I hope,
I'me ready here to hugge
The most ingenious torments on these termes,
That she and you'le be pleas'd;
Wert to encounter a whole host of fiends,
Never to sleepe but in a Dragons den;
Or from the bowells of the burning hill
To fetch a cole, eate fire, or drinke a cup
Of Mercurie precipitat, Ile do't,
And thinke it an Elisium, if it may
Redeeme your loves, and state me once agen
In your esteeme.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: 'Tis well, I doe commend your forward minde;
But this will never doo't;
There's nothing but a marriage will admit
A thought of remedy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nothing but marriage?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Not any thing ith' world but Marriage▪

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: No indeede.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Mercilesse Planets, will ye still goe on,
To heape these hills of mischiefe on my necke,
Or can misfortune reach a higher pitch
In him whose miserie is intollerable,
And remedie impossible, O no;
Sir, in a word,
Your daughter's quite undone, and so am I.

sp.speaker: Sir, T.
sp.l: How stands the businesse?
Speake the worst, if truth, and let me die.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis in vaine to counterfeit,
Or build up castles where they cannot stand;
Doe with me what ye please, the truth is this,
I am already married.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: How? already married?
Villaine, keepe in that breath;
The repetition of these words wud teare
A heart of brasse— already married?
Didst thou ensnare my childe for this?
Hast thou betrayed her white innocence for this?
Blasted the blossome of her virgin spring,
And married now another?
Canst hope or dreame, that e're thy perjur'd soule
Shall see th' Elisian groves?
Hold heart from breaking, now or never hold,
Married to another?
Shall I be bandy'd thus for ever twixt
Rackets of shame and misery,
Cud fate finde ne're a football but my selfe
To tosse and spurne— umph?
Hell and the furies doe conspire I thinke,
To cull out me from all the rest oth' world
To vent their mischiefes on, who is't ye have married? speake.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It is unknowne to me sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: I aske ye who 'tis you have married?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir,
Vpon my life I know not who she is.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Has thy leudnesse brought thee to distraction; married, and yee know not to whom? come take him away, 'tis in vaine to talke— but stay a little. Ile see what creature 'tis.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis very true sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: What wilt thou make me mad?
Where is she, in the house?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Officer, goe fetch her hither, Exit Officer.
Ile make her tell me who she is,
If she can:
sp.p: Married already quoth a? and ye know not to whom neither, here's a marriage with a vengeance.

div.stage: Enter Fairefaith and Sportlove, who were present at the marriage leading betwixt them Sabina veil'd, they present her to her Father, Hilts attending them.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: We heard ye sent for my cosin Valentines wife sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: I did so.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: We have brought her to you sir, here she is sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Very well, in good time: what are you gentlewoman? whence are ye? ha?— speake; nay, if you will not give me an account, I must punish ye; Sabina unpins her maske, and falls upon her knees to her Father.
sp.l: — let not my eyes surfeit— what my Sabina?
My lovely Girle?
Thrice welcome to my bosome?
My Sabina? my daughter, and the wife
Of this my deared friend, unexpected felicitie,
sp.stage: Enter Sir Plenteous with Trash and Rowland.
sp.l: Sir Plenteous? welcome thrice noble sir Plenteous;
But stay
Gentlemen, pray ye present her to her husband first,
sp.stage: Fairefaith and Sportlove present her to Valentine.
sp.l: Sweet sir Plenteous, how dee sir?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Dee know me sir, nay gaze on sir.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: He knowes her present I see that.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Know her? he has beene familiarly with her— before man, and that thee didst not know.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Gaze on still sir,
I'me not Sabinaes ghost, but her poore selfe;
Here stands the creature that was wrong'd by thee,
The very selfesame that you married sir:
What dost thou thinke?
Dost thou not tremble, lest I shud begin,
To number up my wrongs?
I that was lull'd ith' bosome of my friends,
And as 'twere dandl'd on a Fathers knee;
Forfeited all this favour, and was made
A stranger to his eye for love to thee;
Yet thou
Like the prodigious Monster of the world
Ingratitude, didst labour to forget,
Not my love onely, but those sacred vowes
Have past betwixt us; but to be short,
Thus— thus I revenge my selfe. Kisses him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O my Sabina!
It is too sweete and loving a revenge
Vpon so vile a miscreant.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Come
Let the remembrance of these matters dye,
And be confin'd to dust, let 'em be trod
Into the very center of the earth,
Never to rise againe; and let our loves
For ever twine like twins;
What's past I have forgot and pardon'd.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Seale it, or else I die; Kisses him agen.
Live, O live!
A rare example to all future times
Of constancie in love.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.l: Daughter, my heart bids thee welcome,
This night my house shall give thee entertainement,
Whereof thy selfe shall be sole governesse,
And when the icie hand of death shall drive
My soule out of this clod,
It shall be his and thine.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: But gentlemen, me thinkes I long to heare
The storie of this marriage, how it come to passe;
For did I know't, I shud adore the starre,
Vnder whose influence she was brought t'arive
Midst stormes of woe upon this shore of blisse.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.l: Sir, I doe thinke 'twill be
A seasonable discourse for supper;
Suspend but your desires till then
And you shall be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: With all my heart, with all my heart, but sonne, I have one petition to preferre to you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You may stile it a command sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: You must needs bestow upon me your servant Trash.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Heyda? now I'me a beg'd foole, I see that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sirra, attend my father.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Your worships humble servant sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: In all this businesse I have observed in thee
Discretion— judgement— wit— and police;
Therefore
I doe appoint thee Steward of my house,
And put into thy charge the overseeing
Of all my businesses.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Nay sir, for an oversight in any businesse let me alone.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: And what is more.
Dispose my house and servants as you please.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Hilts, come hither— Sirra, doe you waite upon me.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I did ever thinke thou wudst come to some good, for thou hast beene alwayes an honest Trojan; Dee heare, if you had carried me to Bridewell, when ye were bid— where had your proferments beene then Hilts.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Mr. Fairefaith, for you,
I doe perceive your ingenuitie,
Has beene a meanes to make my comfort swell;
And for returne, J doe bestow on thee
My daughter Mirabell.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Sir, your returnes are farre beyond the claime
Of my deserts; and though J am not fit
To bandy favours with so brave a Knight,
Yet I will stretch my studes to expresse
A detestation of ingratitude: and now Sabina,
I doe salute thee by the word of Sister, Kisses her.
— but why so dumpish on a sudden— ha?
I know the cause already, 'tis for feare
Your censures on her faults be too severe;
She has given satisfaction where 'twas due,
Her Father's pleas'd, and so we hope are you:
To you she is referr'd, who now are set,
Ready to give your sentences; but yet
Be pleas'd to speake your doome with gentle breath,
Cause you're the Judges of her Life and Death.
